items.item_details:
The Board of Trustees offers an opportunity for the public to address the Board in four sections of the agenda: on matters of concern about Closed Session items; on matters not appearing on the agenda; on action items contained in the Consent Agenda; and prior to voting on any item contained in the Action Agenda. Each speaker is encouraged to submit a comment card to the Board clerk in order to be recognized to speak.
	Per Board Policy, three minutes may be allotted to each speaker with a maximum of 30 minutes per subject. No action or discussion shall be undertaken on any public comments except that members of the Board or its staff may briefly respond to or ask a question for clarification regarding statements made or questions posed by persons addressing the Board under this agenda item.
	For information and disability access to materials, call 408-270-6402. Meetings are held in a location accessible to the disabled.

items.item_details: The District employs non-bargaining unit employees in various categories to support programs and services.  These categories are: short-term assignments with limitations as defined in the CSEA/District collective bargaining agreement; substitutes to fill positions for employees on leave of absence or in vacant positions; professional experts with specialized knowledge or expertise not generally required of, or found within, the employee classifications established by the Governing Board; and athletic support staff for athletic activities.

The proposed courses have been reviewed by the appropriate instructional administrator and approved by the All-College Curriculum Committee, acting on behalf of the local Academic Senate.  The rigor of the approval process assures that each new course have substance and integrity in relation to its discipline and that it fills a clear student need not being served by existing course offerings.  The list of the new courses are:
	 
BIS 106:  Microsoft Word
BUS 004:  Writing Your Business Plan
BUS 006:  Introduction to Small Business Management
BUS 009:  Introduction to Entrepreneurship
HIST 099:  History Fundamentals

items.item_details: Oral reports will be given by members of the Board of Trustees.
Oral reports will be given by Chancellor Rita Cepeda.
Oral reports will be given by the college presidents.
Oral reports will be given by the constituency representatives.

The 2025 Facilities Master Plans for San Jose City College and Evergreen Valley College were approved by the Board on January 25, 2011. Since that time, the Colleges have developed a more comprehensive understanding of the needs of their unique sites, facilities and educational planning over the 2025 horizon and have engaged a process to update the 2025 Facilities Master Plans with this new knowledge. 
	 
These updated Facilities Master Plans will serve as planning tools to assist in future decision making at each College.  These plans were preceded by the development of the 2025 Educational Master Plans, adopted by the Board in July, 2010. The Facilities Master Plans are intended to provide a guide for future campus development utilizing current and future funding as it is realized. 
	 
The updated Facilities Master Plans detail physical changes to the Colleges that have occurred since the previous master plans and delineate proposed additional physical changes to the Colleges that may occur by the end of 2025 through implementation of these plans.  This includes buildings and facilities that will be demolished, constructed or renovated, as well as comprehensive views of circulation, way finding, landscape, and infrastructure.  These updated plans represent the outcome of collaborative, inclusive processes facilitated by both colleges under the leadership of their respective Presidents and Vice Presidents. The process included the review and participation of faculty, staff, administrators and community members who provided valuable insight and suggestions throughout the development of the plans. Gilbane Building Company and HMC Architects were engaged to assist the Colleges and to facilitate the process.
 
	Vice President Henry Gee will present on the process and proposed revisions to the EVC Facilities Master Plan. Vice President Greg Nelson will present the process and proposed revisions to the San Jose City College Facilities Master Plan.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the Updated Facilities Master Plans for San Jose City College and Evergreen Valley College.

items.item_details:
As part of the accountability measures for the Measure G-2010 Bond Program, the management team for the program has put into place a formal process for managing, tracking and presenting to the Board of Trustees all revisions to the Measure G-2010 individual project names, scopes and budgets. This process adheres to the accountability standards outlined by Proposition 39 and provides transparency in the evolution of the project list. 
	 
This Bond List Revision reflects the collaborative efforts by the Bond Management Team to plan and prioritize Measure G-2010 Bond projects at San Jose City College and Evergreen Valley College. These project revisions are the result of careful coordination and realignment with the current Facilities Master Plans and the planned implementation of the projects at each campus. The project revisions included in this Bond List Revision have been vetted and approved through the shared governance processes at each college.
	 
Measure G-2010 Bond List Revision #1 includes the following project revisions:
	 
San Jose City College Project List Revisions:
Project 31105 Renovate Building K: The College has determined to renovate Building K as a new home for Maintenance & Operations in lieu of building a new facility. The name and budget for this project have been revised to reflect the intended scope.
Project 31106 Renovate - General Education Building: The current Facilities Master Plan includes a new GE facility, however the College has determined that with some minor improvements, the life of the existing GE facility can be extended several more years until funding is available to replace it. This project is being removed from the Bond List, but the College intends to incorporate certain mechanical and finish upgrades to the existing facility into Project 31304 Scheduled Maintenance.
Project 31107 Theater-Drama & Speech Bldg: A recent Facilities Condition Assessment of the existing Theater building indicates that this facility would be costly to renovate and would still not improve some aspects of the facilities’ functionality and efficiency. The College has decided to build a new facility per the current Facilities Master Plan in lieu of renovating the existing facility. The changes to this project’s name and budget reflect the College's current intent for the scope of this project.
Project 31108 100-200-Boiler Plant Demo & New Parking Lot: The demolition of the 300 Building has been removed from the scope of this project and the demolition of the Boiler Plant and a new parking lot have been added to reflect the intent of the current Facilities Master Plan and the planned sequence of implementation of the bond projects. 
Project 31109 Demolition:  Boiler Plant: The scope and budget for this project have been consolidated with Project 31108.
Project 31304 Scheduled Maintenance: The intent of this project remains to provide funding for various maintenance related projects over a 10 year period. This project revision shortens and simplifies the name of the project.
Project 31305 Energy Efficiency - Photovoltaic: The intent of this project is to provide increased energy efficiency and to offset the cost of future energy related utility bills. Although the scope and budget for this project has been consolidated with Project 31113, the budget amount associated with this transfer is dedicated to the installation of a Photovoltaic or other District approved alternative energy generation system. 
Project 31111 Exterior Lighting Phase II, 31117 Landscaping, 31118 Irrigation, 31119 Hardscape & 31120 Wayfinding: The scope and budget for these site related projects have been combined into one new project, Project 31116 Campus Site Improvements, to gain efficiency, economy of scale and to accommodate a holistic approach in developing a comprehensive and consistent design for the campus wide site improvements. 
Project: 31113 Vocational Technology Bldg: This new project as identified in the current Facilities Master Plan is noted as one of the College’s highest priorities. This new facility is required due to the planned demolition of the 100-200-300 buildings that currently house the Vocational Technology programs. Scope and budget from Project 31305 has been consolidated into this project; this transferred scope and budget is intended to remain dedicated to the installation of a Photovoltaic or other District approved alternative energy generation system. 
Project: 31114 Demo 300: This new project has been budgeted in accordance with the intended scope, separated from Project 31108 and established as a unique project due to the planned implementation sequence of the bond projects. 
Project: 31115 Theater Demo & New Parking Lot: This new project includes the demolition of the existing theater and associated site improvements once it is removed. These elements are planned as a separate project once the new theater is complete. 
Project: 31116 Campus Site Improvements: This new project is a consolidation of several site related projects that were individually identified on the original Bond List including Project 31111 Exterior Lighting Phase II, 31117 Landscaping, 31118 Irrigation, 31119 Hardscape & 31120 Wayfinding: The benefits of combining these projects include the ability to take a holistic approach in the development of a comprehensive and consistent design for campus wide site improvements including walkways, landscape, irrigation and lighting.
Project 39905 Management and Related Costs (3% of const hard costs): This budget line item was originally established for Program and Construction Management services at 12% of the total construction budget, with Program Management services accounting for 3% and Construction Management services accounting for 9% of the total Construction Budget. The Bond Executive Team has made the determination to retain the 3% budget allocation for Program Management services in this line item and to reallocate the remaining 9% for Construction Management services to the projects.
	 
As part of this distribution, the following projects received amounts equal to 9% of their currently forecasted Construction 
31107, 31108, 31110, 31304, 31307, 31308, 31112, 31321, 31113, 31114, 31115, 31116, 31311
Project 31199 Campus Contingency: Received the balance of the 9% Construction Management budget not allocated to the above noted projects.
Project 31311 Physical Security: The scope and budget for this project has been adjusted to reflect the College’s current needs and intended scope related to increasing physical security on campus.
	 
	 
Evergreen Valley College Project List Revisions:
Project 32105 New Campus Police Bldg: The District and College have determined that the campus police will remain in their existing facility in lieu of relocating to a new facility. This project is therefore not necessary, is being removed from the Bond List and the budget is being re-directed to address higher priority projects on this list.
Project 32106 Engineering & Applied Technology: The Automotive Technology scope and budget have been removed from this project and established as a separate project. The name and budget for this project have been revised to reflect the currently intended scope.
Project 32107 Science/Math Building(s): The GED4 scope and budget have been removed from this project and established as a separate project. The name and budget for this project have been revised to reflect the currently intended scope.
Project 32108 Admin & Student Services Remodel & Consolidation: The name and budget for this project have been revised to reflect the currently intended scope.
Project 32110 Demolition - Roble/Acacia: The budget for this project has been revised to reflect the current estimate for the intended scope of the project.
Project 32306 Central Plant - Remodel: The name and budget for this project have been revised to reflect the intended scope and current estimate for the project.
Project 32307 Scheduled Maintenance: The intent of this project remains to provide funding for various maintenance related projects over a 10 year period. This project revision shortens and simplifies the name of the project.
Project 32308 Utilities Projects & Upgrades: This project revision includes a change to the project name only to more accurately align with the intended scope and budget. 
Project 32309 Exterior Lighting Upgrade Phase II: The scope and budget for this project have been consolidated with Project 32113.
Project 32312 Vehicular Circulation, 32118 Hardscape- Circulation & Plazas, 32119 Landscaping, 32120 Irrigation & 32121 Wayfinding: The scope and budget for these site related projects have been combined into one new project, Project 32113 Campus Site Improvements, to gain efficiency, economy of scale and to accommodate a holistic approach in developing a comprehensive and consistent design for the campus wide site improvements. 
Project 32111 Autotech: The scope and budget for this project have been aligned with the intended scope, separated from Project 32106 and established as a unique new project due to the planned implementation sequence of the bond projects.
Project 32112 GED 4: The scope and budget for this project have been aligned with the intended scope, separated from Project 32107 and established as a unique new project due to the planned implementation sequence of the bond projects.
Project 32113 Campus Site Improvements: This new project is a consolidation of several site related projects that were individually identified on the original Bond List, including Project 32312 Vehicular Circulation, 32118 Hardscape- Circulation & Plazas, 32119 Landscaping, 32120 Irrigation & 32121 Wayfinding. The benefits of combining these projects include the ability to take a holistic approach in the development of a comprehensive and consistent design for campus wide site improvements including walkways, landscape, irrigation and lighting.
Project 39905 Management and Related Costs (3% of const hard costs): This budget line item was originally established for Program and Construction Management services at 12% of the total construction budget, with Program Management services accounting for 3% and Construction Management services accounting for 9% of the total Construction Budget. The Bond Executive Team has made the determination to retain the 3% budget allocation for Program Management services in this line item and to reallocate the remaining 9% for Construction Management services to the projects.
As part of this distribution, the following projects received amounts equal to 9% of their currently forecasted Construction Budgets:
32106, 32107, 32108, 32109, 32110, 32306, 32307, 32308, 32310, 32311, 32313, 32111, 32112, 32113, 32314
 Project 32299 Campus Contingency: Received the balance of the 9% Construction Management budget not allocated to the above noted projects.
Project  32314 Physical Security: The scope and budget for this project has been adjusted to reflect the College’s current needs and intended scope related to increasing physical security on campus.
	 
District Project List Revisions:
Project 39905 Management and Related Costs (3% of const hard costs): This budget line item was originally established for Program and Construction Management services at 12% of the total construction budget, with Program Management services accounting for 3% and Construction Management services accounting for 9% of the total Construction Budget. The Bond Executive Team has made the determination to retain the 3% budget allocation for Program Management services in this line item and to reallocate the remaining 9% for Construction Management services to the projects. 
	 
As part of this distribution, the following projects received amounts equal to 9% of their currently forecasted Construction Budgets:
39301, 39310, 39308, 39311
	 
Project 39399 Total District/District-wide Contingency received the balance of the 9% Construction Management budget not allocated to the above noted projects.
39699 Program Contingency: This project was re-named to reflect a simpler and more accurate project name.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Measure G-2010 Bond List Revision #1 as detailed in the attachment.

items.item_details:
California Senate Bill 1143 (Chapter 409, Status of 2010) required the California Community Colleges Board of Governors to establish a task force to examine best practices for promoting student success and to adopt a plan for improving degree and completion rates.  On September 30, 2011, the task force completed its report including 22 recommendations  and shared it with the field.  It is expected that that Board of Governors will review these recommendations for adoption at their January 9, 2012 meeting as a "single-reading action" item.  Significant concerns have arisen systemwide regarding the proposed recommendations associated with the substantive nature of the recommendations that, if adopted, will result in changes to the community college mission, the subsequent  necessary changes to Title 5 of the Administrative Code and the Education Code required for implementation, and the relative short period of time to evaluate the programmatic and fiscal impact of the recommendations on the colleges and the students we purport to serve.
	 
This resolution is aligned with the San Jose-Evergreen Community College District Board of Trustees'  direction about the need for thoughtful implementation of its own student success policies, and it is responsive to the concerns raised by the Academic Senates of both colleges and the Faculty Association.  In addition, it adds a voice to the significant number of concerns raised by other governing boards and representatives from the instructional, student services and administrative ranks systemwide.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Resolution No. 112911-3 expressing concern and in response to the California Community Colleges Task Force on Student Success Report.
items.item_text: Board of Trustees Resolution in Response to the California Community Colleges Task Force on Student Success Recommendations

items.item_details:
With student learning as our primary focus, Evergreen Valley College takes great pride in preparing all students of all ages and backgrounds for balanced and productive lives, so they can improve the quality of life in our communities. We, therefore, empower our students to expand their human potential and to succeed in a global, multicultural society.
	 
This presentation will highlight Evergreen Valley College as a collective community that puts students at its center.  Driven by the college’s mission and the guiding principles of equity, opportunity, and social justice, Evergreen Valley College serves a diverse student body of over 9,000 students attending day and evening classes.  We meet our mission through a wide spectrum of educational experiences, flexible methodologies and support services.
	 
This presentation is designed to demonstrate the holistic approach in place at Evergreen Valley College that aligns both instruction and student services  in direct relationship to the needs of our students.  The ultimate goal is to create and sustain a partnership designed to enhance a supportive learning environment.
Chancellor Cepeda will provide a budget update.
Chancellor Cepeda will provide a legislative update.

The Evergreen Valley College campus sits within a State-designated Alquist-Priolo Special Study Zone due to its location adjacent to the Evergreen Fault.  Alquist-Priolo requires a geologic investigation, evaluation and written report by a licensed geologist to demonstrate that proposed buildings will not be constructed across active faults.  
	 
In 1994 the District commissioned a geologic study of the Evergreen Fault north of the campus to determine the limits and suitability of that portion of land for future buildings.  That evaluation identified the relation of the fault to the existing Roble and Acacia buildings, and suitability of proposed building sites in consideration at that time.  The report stated that although Evergreen Valley College sits within an Alquist-Priolo zone, the Evergreen Fault is not considered to be an active fault.  
	 
In 2007 the California Geologic Survey issued Publication 42, “Fault Rupture Hazard Zones in California” that defined the requirements of the Alquist-Priolo Earthquake Fault Zone Act to include an area within 50 feet of an active fault as a no-build zone. 
	 
As part of the development of the Facilities Master Plan for Evergreen Valley College presented to the Board in January 2011, the fault line information was updated and depicted on the Evergreen Facilities Master Plan site plan.  That plan showed Roble and Acacia to be within the established no-build zone.  URS, the successor firm to the initial geologist Woodward-Clyde, provided an update to their preliminary report that stated the Evergreen Fault has been, based on more recent investigations, been designated as “active” by the State.  With this updated information, the District has undertaken various tasks related to assessing the impacts, options and responsibilities of the District.  These include estimates of building relocation, discussions with the State Chancellor’s Office and update to the planning and scheduling of Measure G-2010 projects.   
	 
This presentation is to inform the Board and identify current and future activities related to the Evergreen fault and Evergreen Valley College.

The purpose of this item is to detail the outcome of the process resulting from Request for Qualifications (RFQ) and Request for Proposal (RFP) #G2010.0003 designed to provide the district with services for the Development of District-Owned Land and Possible Relocation of the District Office.  The deadline for submittal of proposals was September 23, 2011.  Selected applicants were further required to participate in an interview process.  The outcomes of that interview were evaluated and led to the recommendation below.  The rank and review document is attached.
	 
The selection and evaluation process is included in the RFQ/RFP a copy of which is also attached.  The recommended consultants met and exceeded all the requirements; and in addition this recommendation is responsive to the Board’s interest to support locally owned and women and minority owned businesses.
	 
Scope A – Long Term Ground Lease of Surplus Land
Selected: Andy Plescia / Gruen Gruen and Associates Team
Reasons: Regional (Sacramento & San Francisco), but in Bay Area regularly working on other projects.  (i.e.: Ohlone College); Competitive fee structure; Small team; Presented well; Came across as comfortable/easy to work with and could communicate with stakeholders in the same manner; Works with community colleges, schools and public entities in California and other states; 
	 
Scope B – Proposed Relocation of District Office and Workforce Institute
Selected: Public Property Advisors (Lisa Gillmor)
Reasons: Locally owned small business will be submitting a women owned business application in early 2012; Works with schools and community college districts throughout California; Extensive knowledge and experience with local regulatory, oversight and governing bodies.
Note:  Public Property Advisors is a division of Gillmor and Associates
